title: Doubling the cube
summary: Doubling the cube, also known as the Delian problem, is an ancient[lower-alpha 1][1]: 9  geometric problem. Given the edge of a cube, the problem requires the construction of the edge of a second cube whose volume is double that of the first. As with the related problems of squaring the circle and trisecting the angle, doubling the cube is now known to be impossible to construct by using only a compass and straightedge, but even in ancient times solutions were known that employed other tools.
